Dear Mr. Derrick McCree:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Health services; policies and procedures.
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4142
Section (1) An institution shall establish and follow written health service
Description policies and procedures addressing all of the following:
(a) Routine and emergency medical, and dental, and behavioral
health care.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Allegation #1
It is alleged that Youth A is being overmedicated and given
medications that are contradictory in nature.
Allegation #2
The agency denied giving Youth A his glasses, although he is
visually impaired.
Investigation
Allegation #1
It is alleged that Youth A is being overmedicated and given
medications that are contradictory in nature.
Complainant:
On 11/12/24, I spoke to Complainant via telephone. Complainant
did not provide any more details to this allegation.
Therapist 1:
On 11/25/24, I interviewed Therapist 1 face to face at the facility.
Therapist 1 reported Youth A was receiving the medications
prescribed to him by the psychiatrist. Therapist 1 reported Foster
Care Worker 1 approved the medications by signing the medical
sheets. Therapist 1 reported the psychiatrist prescribed the
medication and the agency filled that medication and administered
it. Therapist 1 reported she has never heard Youth A complain
about his medications. Therapist 1 reported Youth A does not
present lethargic but active.
Youth A:
Youth A was interviewed face to face at St. Clair Treatment
Center on 2/6/25. Youth A reported he has never had any issues
with his medications.
2

Documents Reviewed:
• Intake document recorded Youth A’s admittance on
6/27/24.
• Initial Psychiatric Evaluation completed on 7/14/24. Current
medications were noted as Vyvanse 70mg, Abilify 10mg,
Olanzapine 20mg, Trazadone 150mg, Sertraline 150mg.
Recommendations: Youth A had already started his
medications from a previous agency and a medical consent
form will be obtained for additional medications prescribed.
• Medication Consent Forms were signed by Worker 1 on
8/16/24 and Psychiatrist 1 on 7/24/24. The following
medications were added: Depakote 250mg, Zyprexa
2.5mg, Atarax 25mg. There were no other medical consent
forms.
• I reviewed the Health Services Policies and Procedures.
o “All medications administered to youth are to be
ordered in writing by agency physicians. Medications
and prescriptions will be accompanying youth
transferring from other institutions will be reviewed
and verified by an agency physician and
reordered…”
Allegation #2:
The agency denied giving Youth A his glasses, although he is
visually impaired.
Therapist 1
On 11/25/24, I interviewed Therapist 1 at the facility. Therapist 1
reported Youth A broke an “arm” off his glasses to self-harm.
Because of his behaviors, they took the glasses from him.
Therapist 1 did not know the specific date, but reported they would
have given him the glasses back if they knew he could be safe
with them.
Supervisor 1 and Staff 1:
On 12/19/24 Supervisor 1 and Staff 1 were interviewed separately
at the facility. Both reported Youth A broke his glasses and due to
safety concerns involving self harm, they were removed from him
when he was on suicide watch.
Youth A:
Youth A was interviewed on 2/6/25 face to face at St. Clair
Treatment Center. Youth A did not want to discuss this topic.
3

Documents:
• I reviewed the Use of Safety Precautions for Youth At Risk
policy. Items that pose a threat to the youth are to be
removed from their physical location.
• I reviewed the Suicide Precaution Forms. Youth A was
placed on suicide precaution multiple times at a Level 3.
• I reviewed the Emergency Hospital Visit Documents. Youth
A was observed and stayed extensive nights at the hospital
due to the inability to keep himself and others safe. Hospital
restraints were completed to keep him from harming
himself and others.
Analysis Allegation #1: The agency is compliant with this rule. Youth A
continued taking his previously prescribed medications once
admitted to Lincoln. After his Initial Psychiatric Evaluation, the
psychiatrist added medications. These medications were
approved by Worker 1. Medications were prescribed by the
attending physician as outlined in the policy.
Allegation #2: The agency is compliant with this rule. The agency
followed their behavioral health care policy on Use of Safety
Precautions for Youth At Risk. Youth A demonstrated unsafe
behaviors, which would lead to the agency removing any objects
(glasses) that could cause harm to Youth A.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code Program statement
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4109
Section (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program
Description statement which specifically addresses all of the following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care,
safety, and supervision, methods for addressing residents' needs,
implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type Additional Rule Violation
Allegation Allegation #1: Youth A is experiencing unmanaged mental health
issues.
Additional Rule Violation
Allegation #2: The agency did not follow their suicide precaution
policy.
4

Investigation
Therapist 1:
I interviewed Therapist 1 on 11/25/24 and 1/16/25. Therapist 1
reported she completes individual therapy sessions once a week
with Youth A. Therapist 1 reported Youth A has significant trauma
history, and his mental health can be unstable. Therapist 1
reported Youth A has spent time on suicide watch. When Youth A
was on suicide watch and behind a locked bedroom door, she did
not enter to provide therapy sessions, but did check on him.
Therapist 1 reported only a supervisor, or manager could open the
door when a youth entered suicide watch in their room. Therapist
1 reported she would not have felt safe completing the therapy
session with the door open. Therapist 1 reported it was unsafe for
her to open the door to talk to Youth A, due to possible physical
aggression. Therapist 1 reported she thought it was okay to do
check ins. Therapist 1 reported a “check in” was standing outside
of the locked bedroom door and asking Youth A how he was doing
in his room, what he could be working on while waiting for the
psychiatrist to evaluate him and redirecting him to his behaviors
that placed him in the suicide watch room.
A follow up interview was conducted on 2/13/25 via telephone.
Therapist 1 reported there was only one therapy session
scheduled with Youth A’s family. Therapist 1 reported she was
given permission by the Foster Care Worker 1 to have family
involved. Therapist 1 reported she did not case note this
interaction with Foster Care Worker 1 and did not know the exact
date this was stated. Therapist 1 reported group sessions did not
have a structured topic schedule. The topics were based on what
was occurring at that time with the unit. At times, they discussed
healthy boundaries, following directions, peer relationships in the
group, and communication. Therapist 1 reported her written case
notes did not address all the topics they discussed and at times
the weekly case notes pertaining to group topics were not updated
well. Therapist 1 did review some case notes with this consultant
and was able to verbalize that some of the case notes started to
be generic in nature and there were some that were not updated
from week to week. Therapist 1 did acknowledge that the case
noting could be more specific outlining the services and topics the
agency was providing. Therapist 1 reported psychoeducation
pertaining to victimization and STD’s did not occur because Youth
A was not at the level he needed to be to engage in this area.
Therapist 1 reported Youth A was not willing to engage in
treatment.
5

Youth C, Youth D, and Youth E were interviewed separately on
11/25/24 at the facility. All reported Youth A was "always”" on
suicide watch in his room.
Youth A:
Youth A was interviewed face to face at St. Clair Treatment
Center on 2/6/25. Youth A would not provide any details
concerning his therapy or treatment at Lincoln Center. Youth A
reported he was tired and did not want to talk anymore.
Documents Reviewed:
• Youth A’s Updated Treatment Plan dated 7/27/24-
10/25/24 outlines the following services to be provided:
“Individual therapy each week and group therapy at least
five times weekly. Anger management groups and
substance abuse treatment groups…family therapy offered
once monthly.” The report states Youth A was offered
individual and group sessions when “he is not on suicide
precautions.”
o Individual Therapy: Youth A did not receive
individual therapy sessions four times this reporting
period. On the following specific dates, he was
“observed”: 8/16/24, 9/20/24, 10/11/24, and
10/25/24.
o Family Therapy: There are no reported family
therapy sessions. One was scheduled on 9/24/24
but Youth A went to the hospital for suicide ideations
and did not have this completed. No make up
session was completed. No other dates of family
sessions were stated to be offered to the family
since entry into the program on 6/27/24. Treatment
plan states agency will provide family therapy.
o Anger Management Groups: There are no
statements in the treatment plan that discuss the
attendance of anger management groups or topics
discussed. (See below for further group sessions).
o Substance Abuse Treatment Groups: The
treatment plan does not discuss if Youth A is
involved in these groups, nor does it discuss if the
services outlined by the provider were given to
Youth A.
o Psychoeducation related around healthy and
unhealthy relationships: This service is to be
provided under social relations goals. This service is
not noted as being provided.
6

o Psychoeducation related around direct and
indirect victimization: This service is to be
provided under victimization goals. This service is
not noted as being provided.
o Psychoeducation related to regarding STDs and
STIs: This service is not noted as being provided.
• Individual Therapy Session notes for the following
dates:
(Note: *The report states Youth A was offered individual
and group sessions when “he is not on suicide
precautions.”)
o 7/21/24-7/27/24: Five group sessions offered, stated
he was involved in group sessions all five days.
From 7/24/24-7/26/24, Youth A was in suicide
precaution; therefore, unable to be in the group
sessions, as stated in note above.
o 8/5/24-8/10/24: Five group sessions offered, stated
he was involved in all five. Youth A was on suicide
precaution from 8/5/24 with no end date noted;
therefore, unable to be in the group sessions as
stated in the note above.
o 8/11/24-8/17/24: Five group sessions offered, stated
he was involved in all five. Youth A was on suicide
watch from 8/13/24-8/15/24, therefore; unable to be
in the group sessions as stated in the noted above.
o 8/18/24-8/24/24: Five group sessions were noted,
and it was stated Youth A was “unable to participate
in most groups to being on suicide precautions.”
There are no suicide precaution documents for these
dates. (See below rule violation.)
o 8/25/24-8/31/24: Five group sessions were noted,
and it was stated Youth A was “unable to participate
in most groups to being on suicide precautions.”
There are no suicide precaution documents for these
dates.
o 9/1/24-9/7/24: Five group sessions were noted, and
it was stated Youth A was “unable to participate in
most groups to being on suicide precautions.” There
are no suicide precaution documents for these
dates.
o 9/8/24-9/14/24: Case notes do not state whether
Youth A was in group sessions this week. There are
no suicide precaution documents for this week.
7

o 9/15/24-9/21/24: Case notes do not state whether
Youth A was in group sessions this week. There are
no suicide precaution documents for this week.
o 9/22/24-9/28/24: Case notes do not state whether
Youth A was in group sessions this week. Youth A
was on suicide precaution from 9/23/24-9/27/24.
o 9/29/24-10/5/24: Case notes do not state whether
Youth A was in group sessions this week. Youth A
was at the hospital on 10/1/24 and 10/4/24.
o 10/6/24-10/12/24: Youth A did not participate in
groups due to being at the hospital
o 10/13/24-10/19/24: Youth A did not participate in
groups due to being at the hospital
o 10/20/24-10/26/24: Youth A did not participate in
groups due to being at the hospital
• I reviewed the Program Statement for Lincoln Center:
Individual therapy, case conferences, family therapy, group
therapy, rational behavior training, psychiatric services, and
clinical services are to be provide to the youth.
• I reviewed Youth A’s Initial Psychiatric Evaluation
completed on 7/14/24 and subsequent evaluations
completed on 8/11, 8/15, 9/27, and 10/19.
• I reviewed Youth A’s emergency hospital treatment
documents from Children’s Hospital of Michigan. Youth A
was at the hospital on the following dates: 10/1-10/2, 10/4-
14, 10/22-10/24.
• I reviewed Youth A’s MAR’s documents. Medication was
given/offered as prescribed.
Allegation #2: The agency did not follow their suicide precaution
policy.
Documents Reviewed:
• I reviewed the Use of Safety Precautions for Youth At Risk
policy.
o Level 3: continuous supervision, restriction of the
youth’s ability to participate in a group setting, a
restriction of the items the youth may have access
to, and any other interventions deemed clinically
necessary to maintain the youth’s safety…
o Moving youth under evaluation to an assigned
room…
o Youth on Level 3…may be removed from their
rooms for hygiene and recreation to the extent that it
8

can be done safely. When a youth is on Level 3
precautions is to be let out of their room, staff will
notify a co-worker and the safety support coordinator
prior to allowing the youth to leave their room…
o In cases where the youth is placed under safety
precautions after being placed into seclusion, the
consulting psychiatrist shall ensure that staff has
completed processing of the behavior leading to
seclusion. The youth should be calm and no longer
require the use of the seclusion room prior to
authorizing the removal of safety precautions.
o The consulting psychiatrist shall evaluate the youth
considered to be at risk for suicide…an coordinate
any changes with the facility manager.
o The following documents are to be completed under
this policy:
▪ Unusual Incident Report
▪ Safety Precaution Initial Level Form
▪ Safety Precautions Level Change Form
• I reviewed the following Unusual Incident Reports noting
Youth A placed on Suicide Precaution:
o 7/9/24: Initial Level Form was missing.
o 7/24/24: Level Change form was missing.
o 8/5/24: Initial and Level Change forms were missing.
o 10/1/24: Initial and Level Change form missing.
o 10/19/24: Initial and Level Change form missing.
• I reviewed Therapist 1 Case notes. They document Youth
A in suicide precaution from 7/14/24-7/20/24, some dates
from 8/18/24-8/24/24 (specific dates not noted, only the
timeframe,) some dates from 8/25/24-8/31/24 (specific
dates not noted, only the timeframe), some dates
from7/14/24-7/20/24, some dates from 8/18/24-8/24/24
(specific dates not noted, only the timeframe,) some dates
from 8/25/24-8/31/24 (specific dates not noted, only the
timeframe), some dates from 9/1/24-9/7/24, (Specific dates
not noted, only timeframe). There were no documents for
suicide precaution completed on those dates.
Analysis Allegation #1: The agency is in violation of this rule. The program
statement outlines specific aspects of the agency’s program that is
to be integrated into the care and treatment of the youth. Youth A
was not receiving all of the treatment outlined in the program
statement.
• Youth A did not receive individual therapy on 8/16/24,
9/20/24, 10/11/24, and 10/25/24.
9

• Documentation is inconsistent with services. Case notes
written by Therapist 1 reported Youth A participated in
anger management groups, yet Youth A was in suicide
precaution (isolation in his room) during those times.
During the dates 8/18/24-9/7/24, case notes state Youth A
was in suicide precautions and was not involved in anger
management groups, yet there are no suicide precaution
documentation for those dates. From 9/8/24-10/5/24 case
notes do not state whether Youth A was in attendance at
these anger management groups or what his participation
was.
• Family Therapy is only noted as offered once, although it is
to be offered monthly. There is no documentation to
support monthly therapy or offering of family therapy.
Therapist 1 reported the only scheduled family session was
cancelled due to Youth A’s hospitalization.
The agency is found in compliance pertaining to these areas of
treatment.
• Substance Abuse, psychoeducation services pertaining to
relationships, victimization, or STD groups are not
documented, but interview with Therapist 1 confirms Youth
A was not ready to engage in these groups as of yet.
• Youth A was receiving psychiatric services as noted by
evaluations and hospital visits.
• Youth A was receiving medical services as outlined by the
numerous hospital visits and MAR’s documents.
TECHNIAL ASSISTANCE:
Documentation in the treatment plans did not provide updates
pertaining to the actual services that were being provided by the
agency (action steps) and the response (actions steps) of Youth
A. It was noted by Therapist 1 that the action steps in the report
are not individual based but all youth in the program have the
same action steps. Treatment plans are to be client centered.
Youth A’s report had multiple goals within the same time frame to
complete. The agency has stages to treatment (Stage 1, Stage 2,
Stage 3.) and the actions step time frames should coincide with
those stages on paper. Not all goals can be worked on at the
same time. Some goals can be postponed in the treatment plan,
therefore having different time frames of being initiated and
completed. If action steps are not completed within the time frame
noted in the previous reports, then the following treatment plan
should explain why those actions steps were not completed. The
program statement outlines the services that are being provided to
10

all youth. Those services should be discussed within the treatment
plans.
Documentation in the case notes should be client centered and
specific to the youth receiving the services. The case notes should
support the plans in the treatment plan. The agency would benefit
from report writing training and case note training as well as a
training showing the thread of services stemming from the
program statement intertwined with documentation.
Consultation:
If clinical reviews are not being completed at the agency it would
benefit the agency to begin reviews where the treatment plans,
services provided, case notes and progress of a youth are
observed, reviewed, discussed, and assessed. This can be used
as a training tool for those who are writing reports and managing
the unit.
Allegation #2:
The agency is in violation of this rule. The agency is missing
documentation for 7/9/24, 7/24/24, 8/5/24, 10/1/24, and 10/19/24.
Therapist 1’s case notes document more occurrences of suicide
precaution. Those dates, if accurate, are missing all
documentation.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE:
The suicide precaution policy is not in align with Licensing Rules
for Child Caring Institutions. Seclusion is not noted as something
that is to be done for suicide precaution, although the agency
policy does state the agency can do “any other interventions
deemed clinically necessary to maintain the youth’s safety…” This
is vague and does not supersede the licensing rules. The
agency’s current policy waits for the psychiatrist to assess the
youth before being moved off of suicide precaution. This may take
days and in the meantime the youth is isolated and not involved in
programming. Goals are not formally established or a treatment
plan, other than placing the child in the room. The agency will
need to rewrite their suicide precaution assessments to align with
licensing rules.
CONSULTATION:
The policy should be trauma informed and should not decrease
services provided to the youth but intensify them. Specific goals
and interventions should be in place to help the youth, as well as
assessments of those goals. Therapist, facility managers, and
staff should all know the interventions and goals being worked on
11

while on suicide precaution and should be focused on those in
their interactions with the youth.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established

Rule Code Intervention standards and prohibitions
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158
Section (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Description policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not limited to:
(ii) Hitting or striking, throwing, kicking, pulling, or pushing a
youth on any part of their body.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff (unknown) physically assaulted Youth A on unknown dates.
Investigation Youth B, Youth C, Youth D, Youth E, Youth F, Youth G were
interviewed on 11/25/24 face to face at the facility Youth H, Youth
I, and Youth J were all interviewed face to face at the facility on
12/19/24. All youth reported they have never seen any staff
member physically assault any youth. They all reported they never
saw any staff physically assault Youth A.
Youth A
Youth A was interviewed on 2/6/25 face to face at St. Clair
Treatment Center. Youth A reported he was never physically
assaulted by staff at Lincoln Center.
Supervisor 1 and Staff 2:
Both reported they never seen staff physically assault Youth A.
12

Documents Reviewed:
I reviewed the Behavior Management Policy. Physically assaulting
youth is not permitted.
Analysis The agency is compliant with this rule. No one interviewed
reported staff physically assaulted Youth A, including Youth A.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code Sufficiency of staff.
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4126
Section (1) The licensee shall have a sufficient number of administrative,
Description supervisory, social service, direct care, and other staff on duty to
perform the prescribed functions required by these administrative
rules and in the agency's program statement and to provide for the
continual needs, protection, and supervision of residents
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff allegedly did not provide safety to Youth A, which caused
him to be physically assaulted by other youth.
Investigation The following interviews were completed on 11/25/24 at the
facility.
Youth B:
Youth B reported he has seen Youth A hit by other peers. Youth B
reported during those times staff (unknown which staff) intervened
and stopped it.
Youth C:
Youth C reported he fought Youth A due to Youth A spitting on
him. Youth C reported staff (unknown which staff) broke up the
fight.
Youth D:
Youth D reported he got into a fight with Youth A but was
separated by staff (unknown which staff). Youth D did not
remember why they fought.
13

Youth F:
Youth F reported Youth A got into a lot of fights, but staff
(unknown which staff) always broke it up.
The following interviews were completed on 12/19/24 at the
facility.
Supervisor 1:
Supervisor 1 reported Youth A was aggressive towards many
people staff and youth. Supervisor 1 reported she was not around
when Youth A was in physical fights with other youth.
Staff 1:
Staff 1 reported she remembered an incident where Youth A had
called Youth C a “nigger” and then Youth C physically hit Youth A.
Staff 1 reported they responded by physically intervening and
separating them.
Staff 2:
Staff 2 reported she has been present when Youth A has been in
physical fights with other youth. She did not remember any
specific incident. Staff 2 reported the staff on the unit have always
intervened.
The following interviews were completed on 1/16/25 at the facility.
Supervisor 2:
Supervisor 2 reported he has seen fighting occur with Youth A, but
staff have always intervened. Supervisor 2 did not recall a specific
incident.
Staff 3
Staff 3 reported she remembered a time she had to deescalate a
situation with Youth A and Youth C. Because Youth A was calling
him a “nigger”, Youth C punched Youth A and then Youth A
began spitting on him. Staff 3 reported the safety support staff
came into the unit quickly and intervened. Staff 3 reported the
safety support staff were able to come in quickly because they
watch the units on the cameras.
Youth K and Youth L:
Youth K and Youth L both reported they have been in fights with
Youth A after he has spit on them. Both reported staff intervened.
14

Youth K reported the safety support staff came quickly into the
unit.
Youth M
Youth M reported he has never physically assaulted Youth A and
has always seen staff stop other youth from hitting Youth A.
Youth A:
Youth A was interviewed on 2/6/25 face to face at St. Clair
Treatment Center. Youth A did not want to discuss this topic.
Documents Reviewed:
• I reviewed five incident reports noting Youth A being
physically hit by other youth in the unit. All incident reports
noted staff intervened physically by removing and
separating the youth involved, getting in between the youth
or with a restraint.
• I reviewed the Behavior Management Policy. Staff are to
intervene when youth become aggressive.
Analysis The agency is compliant with this rule. All staff and youth
interviewed reported that staff always intervened when youth
became aggressive.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code Seclusion within secure and nonsecure facilities; seclusion
Title plan; prohibitions; reduction and elimination
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4162
Section (11) All seclusions will be prohibited effective November 1. 2022.
Description
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Th facility placed Youth A into seclusion as punishment and kept
him in seclusion for days.
Investigation On 11/25/24 the following interviews were completed face to face
at the facility.
Administrator 2:
Administrator 2 reported Youth A was not in seclusion but was on
suicide watch. Administrator 2 reported suicide watch had different
levels of care. Youth A was placed in his room with staff present
per his level of suicide watch. Administrator 2 reported Youth A
15

was moved to his own unit recently to help assist him in the
program.
Youth C, Youth D, Youth E, and Youth G
These youth were all interviewed separately on 11/25/24 at the
facility. All reported Youth A was "always”" on suicide watch in his
room.
Youth G reported that a staff would sit at his door when in suicide
watch.
Therapist 1
Therapist 1 reported Youth A was placed on suicide watch while
at the facility. Therapist 1 reported when he was placed on suicide
watch he would be placed into his room. The door was locked,
and a staff member would be at his door. Therapist 1 reported
only a supervisor could open the door to his room, due to safety
issues. Therapist 1 reported he would wait in his room until the
psychiatrist would come to the site and meet with him.
Supervisor 1:

Youth A
Youth A was interviewed on 2/6/25 face to face at St. Clair

Documents Reviewed:
• I reviewed the agency’s Seclusion Room and Reintegration
Policy.
• The agency did not have seclusion documents for Youth A,
but did have Suicide Precaution Forms or Incident reports
that placed Youth A in his room on the following dates:
7/9/24-7/10/24, 7/15/24-7/17/24, 7/24/24-7/26/24, 8/5/24-no

• Lincoln currently has a variance approval for R.400.4162
(11). The last approved variance was completed on

youth on “suicide watch.”
Analysis The agency is in violation of this rule. Seclusion, as defined by
Licensing Rules for Child Caring Institutions is the involuntary
placement of a youth in a room alone, where the youth is
prevented from exiting by any means, including the physical
presence of staff person if that staff person’s presence prevents
the youth from exiting the room. The agency placed Youth A
multiple times in his room. The door was locked, and Youth A was
unable to leave the room. In this situation, seclusion could only be
used as a temporary response to behavior that threatens
immediate harm to a youth and then the youth would be removed
from seclusion. The agency has a variance in effect to use
seclusion and they did not follow the guidelines noted in the
variance.
